review: Immigrant lives, millions from everywhere, are taken for granted, disregarded, and misunderstood, often made invisible to the nativist sensibility, anImmigrant lives, millions from everywhere, are taken for granted, disregarded, and misunderstood, often made invisible to the nativist sensibility, and made simple by the simplistic politics of our time. When we read a novel like this one -- coupled as it is to riveting and saddening news of forced emigration and brutal response -- some of that is undone. We gather some small idea of the complexity of displaced lives through the author's authority. Vu Tranh, born in Vietnam and raised in Oklahoma, certainly has a full view of what is too often hidden. The form he has chosen for this telling is somewhat flawed, but the underlying narratives ring true.The book seems to be about crime, but then it seems to be about love, and sometimes it seems to be about rescue. But it isn't about any of these. The protagonist is a policeman, but not a very smart or appealing one. His opponents are shady Vietnamese gamblers and heavy-handed minor gangsters. And the object of his attention is the Vietnamese woman he has lost to a stereotypical, patriarchal semi-mobster. She is a problem without limits, erratic, opaque, haunted, inscrutable (sorry to suggest a stereotype), and seemingly without reality. We never meet her, but she is everywhere in the Las Vegas wind. We sense that she is living with ghosts.What we do know about her, however, comes to us through lengthy and uninvolving diary entries that chronicle her escape from Vietnam, the death of her first husband, an alliance with a fellow escapee (the brutal gambler she turns to ultimately), and her unexpected daughter Mai, for whom the diary is intended. Consequently (though her life is desperate) she remains merely a fiction within a fiction to the reader, not a person we can grasp through dialogue, interaction, or a semblance of living emotion. We know she is not a very predictable person, that her marriage to the policeman was largely enigmatic and incompatible, and we know that she left him with a sense of having failed to save her from herself. Still, it is difficult to care.This novel seems like a crime novel, but it fails to do what fine crime literature does: we have no way to see beyond the situation to some sort of coherent resolution that satisfies and informs. While the author has much honest experience to work with, the diaries are not illuminating to read because they distract the reader even farther from the currently absent wife. To be fair, they chronicle authentic desperation, disappearances, and threats to existence, and in them the duress, isolation, haunting, and despair of immigrant lives are made fairly clear. (And so, three stars.) Yet the hidden psychological experience many people do not wish to see remains intact. The author might have told a less opaque and more moving story had the woman at its center been given an actual presence, and a real voice, in the novel. As it is, she becomes to us merely a ghost of herself....more

review: First novels almost always deserve basic praise for the audacity of the challenge they represent. Sustaining an invented narrative over a long passageFirst novels almost always deserve basic praise for the audacity of the challenge they represent. Sustaining an invented narrative over a long passage of time and complexity is difficult, and to undertake the attempt is bold, and occasionally arrogant. The arrogant writers are easy to address by saying nothing. And for some others, real writing skill and imaginative talent can emerge only after an initial attempt. The great first novel is rare, and yet here is an example of exactly that rarity, in a relatively brief but clearly satisfying form.S. M. Hulse manages at least five strong narrative strands in Black River and any one of them is daunting: a devastating loss, conflict with a son, lasting wounds and inner scars, dealing with crippling bitter memories, and what music means to a man who has lost it. Other themes adroitly play a part in the unrolling of the story. But these five are enough to doom any novel without an artist in control. At its center is Wes Carver -- prison guard, musician, widower, stepfather, mourner -- as he experiences a fraught, angry return to the source of his bitterness. The rawness and depth of anger he shows is not far beneath everyday conversation and it is close to a generalized hatred. It always underlies memory and dialogue, and it stands fully in the way of arriving at a settled heart. Of course none of the losses can be erased or undone; it is his unyielding and grievous intensity that makes Wes the wreckage he is. Hulse is deeply impressive for managing the multiple strands, blending them artfully while introducing contexts, characters and attitudes that nearly match Wes in implacability and obduracy. He is a hardened man outwardly, but as the history of his feelings is told, he is fully exposed in a way I would expect to challenge an experienced master novelist. And more: Hulse is a powerful stylist and graceful narrator, undaunted by the complexity of good and evil in human forms. Black River also does great justice to Montana, not merely as an astonishing landscape, but as the bare place of hard endless winters that both forge and prove personal character. ...more

Nora Webster has seen her husband, Maurice, a respected teacher, die. He leaves Nora and four children, two of whom are not yet in their teens. The family is not lost, but we worry for it, seeing how it has been rocked. Nora is also not lost, but takes time to find the firm self that had disappeared into the construction of a sound marriage. She now has something else to construct for herself and her children. Her tentative steps and second thoughts remind us of where she is: in an Irish community of people who care, but who also judge, suspect, and conspire. For a widow, all change is subject to  and inspection; comments are made. People intrude. Nora lives as though she is in performance before the small-minded audience seated in a narrow theater. Remember, also, this is Ireland, and a civil war is going on.As I felt while reading Tóibín's Brooklyn, he gives us a life so private that it would have disappeared without him, except that, as he writes it, its owner becomes someone new. Enduring the loss of Maurice, Nora is at first tangential, conditional (a widow), and what she had thought permanent is suddenly temporary. It is not so much the loss of the life that matters; it is the loss of the resonance and trust she had known in marriage. Our impermanence, suddenly demonstrated, raises doubts; our doubts raise questions that assail us, holding them up to the light. Our work is to rescue ourselves, or the expectations of loss will be fulfilled. Late in the novel, Nora's self-rescue involves music. review: It would be droll but pointless to put this on my "crime" shelf, but the more I read about Iraq the clearer it is that the nation will pay forever -- It would be droll but pointless to put this on my "crime" shelf, but the more I read about Iraq the clearer it is that the nation will pay forever -- if it can recover from this current steep decline of character -- for the feckless hypocrisy and cruel lies that opened the deadly door to Iraq. Phil Klay's Redeployment is one recent part of the long series of books that carry the most lasting narrative legacies of what we have done to each other with weapons since 1914. The current spate of fresh perspectives on the Battle of the Somme and its sequels reminds any sentient reader of what men and women have endured for decades during and following warfare. The stories here are bitter, cruel, and perfect vessels for the veil of doubt that will hover over the history of soldiering since the watershed of days in 2011. Klay inhabits multiple key actors in these stories -- a military chaplain, a body-gatherer, a burn survivor in a Manhattan bar, for example -- and as he does, the reader thinks: no doubt, no doubt. The idiocy of generals pervades our ideas of the First War and the heroic fight against the perverse Nazi state pervades our narratives of the Second, but beginning with Korea and then Vietnam, and now in the Middle East, we have no comforting nobility to succor us. So here we have a fine work that typifies the lifetime of ambiguous warfare since 1945: the engagement with truth-telling, pervasive ambivalence, impotent anger, bombed out feelings, paranoid hatred and fear, abrasive details of needless death, the murder of families, cruel jokes, addiction to killing, unanswerable questions. On all of these counts, the stories in Redeployment, experiences of Iraq warfare and its aftermath, will serve the human record as long as people read. Just read it, trusting the storyteller, knowing nothing about the story.)A wonderful fiction -- meaning it is gratifying or exquisitely balanced or various and astonishing -- is difficult to describe apart from personal, private words. For a reader of a great work, the machinery and effects are tacit: the great book is words that make its reader wordless. As I read All the Light We Cannot See it seemed unnecessary to describe the experience to myself. It was, in a phrase I admire from Maxine Greene, a lived experience. The author Doerr is really a character here, I think: he is the locksmith at the Museum of Natural History in Paris whose sightless daughter is one of the two centers of the book. The other is a German orphan, an intuitive technologist whose life takes on dimensions through radio transmissions, first as a child and then as a very young German soldier charged with finding the secret transmitters of the French Resistance. He has heard the voice of the daughter in a broadcast, and he is haunted by it, as he is by knowing the deaths he has brought about. The locksmith's daughter is, like the reader, capable of visualizing through senses other than sight. Like her, we are given a model city to touch with our fingertips, while keys open locks, tumblers mesh and secured doors swing open, each one holding some small unclear glimpse of what is to happen. This too is a sign of great fiction: we are given glimpses and fragments in short chapters. So much about this large fiction is small, a miniature of the world in chaos. The true magic of wonderful fiction is that our view of small lives becomes microcosmic, illuminating some larger lost universe we did not know we were reading about....more

At times Doerr reminded me of the Nabokov of Pnin or the great Bernard Malamud's A New Life; I also thought of Saul Bellow and the neglected Edward Lewis Wallant. Doerr's protagonist is haunted and driven, hopeful and enduring, hopeless and fragile. He starts out in Anchorage, runs with his lover to Cleveland (where Grace is born). His prescient dreaming sets him into a frenzy of protective madness. He loses his marriage and child, his job as a weatherman, but not the haunted life he has led. All of this is strangely credible, as it must be, to serve as the foundation for what follows, an attempt to live a life apart from all of its foundations. He is a hydrologist by training -- a specialist in snowflakes -- and scholarly disquisitions about moisture are embedded in the narrative successfully; also, there is a good deal of Alaskan entomology and chill-survival in the book. Further, the major portion of the novel (i.e., post-Cleveland) is set in the Grenadines, on the Caribbean island of St. Vincent. So it is a book of mixed climates, private nightmares, and slow recoveries of strength. We read novels that transcend "real time" by tricky assWe know that time is continuous and inexorable, but we imagine it to be wrinkled or contoured. We read novels that transcend "real time" by tricky assumptions, or compress it with deep details, or vary it through multiple perspectives on one moment. And so it can be destroyed and reconstructed, and relived, in fiction and made less like time as we know it, more like time as we imagine it to be: our experiences kept in the great store that is our brain. (Yesterday, I felt the shame of my schoolchild self, even more vividly than in 1955. I constantly find out that he is not the past at all, and never will be.) The achievements of this extraordinary, brilliant work rely on rendering time as planar and episodic, repeatable with variations and restorations, each episode a different deal of fated cards. Or time is here a flowing unearthly liquid, a medium for floating, a floating world. Toward the end of Life After Life, Atkinson's chosen protagonist Ursula says, "The past seemed to leak into the present, as if there were a fault somewhere. Or was it the future spilling into the past? Either way it was nightmarish, as if her inner dark landscape had become manifest. ... Here too, she thought. She had been here before. She had never been here before. I give in, she thought. Whatever it is, it can have me." I too have been taken over, having given in to this telling, yet it has proven to be unlike any other cedings of awareness to a book. We may know how littleAs generations of witnesses and the value of curiosity disappear from our lives, it is time to forge anew the future of memory. We may know how little we know about the Twentieth Century's most immense homicidal act--the Holocaust, the "final solution"--but our children and their children are likely to know far less than we do. What we do not know is how little we feel until we read a novel, based on truth, like Ostland. Our most important museums and collections, scholarly accounts based on eternal documentation, and some well-known films ("Shoah," "Schindler's List," "Night and Fog") continue to provide chilling historic and visual documentation with evocative voices. What might American culture have been, had 750,000 boys not perished at Gettysburg, Chickamauga, or Spotsylvania? What if the Europeans had not squandered 1.2 million lives at the Somme alone? Imaginable histories, perhaps, but impossible to write.The impossible history is what fiction captures. Life Class and Toby's Room are novels of the First World War by Pat Barker (this  will be posted under both titles) tracing the intimacy and individuality of how the axe of war dismembers the whole body and spirit of a society, starting with its young, its aging survivors, its poets and artists. Barker writes superbly and with almost impossible subtlety and detail about these lives, in such a way that they become contemporary; we can sense them continuing to have lived among us.Before the war, the undamaged art students in Life Class) strive to draw the human form as perfectly as they can; in its aftermath (in Toby's Room), they capture the shattered faces of men who must wear masks in public. These are visual books, extending our experiences far beyond metaphor or war romance to tell us what the protagonists see, leaving us to reconstruct from their lives what they feel and remember, but rarely speak about, when the killing ends. One protagonist, Paul, is driving an ambulance in Belgium when he sees "a dark shape ahead. As he slowed down, it was jointed by a second, and then a third. Men, some of them badly wounded, crawling out of the ditches that lined the road. ... They had no faces, only flaking mud masks with white circles round the eyes and red wet mouths struggling to speak. When words failed, they pointed at their wounds." At another point, the men and the mud of Ypres become indistinguishable, living men turned into dirt. The living dead, rising. More than sixty years ago, at five or six, while I watched my father shave, he pointed to a small scar on his chin, just to the side of his mouth, and told me it was the result of shrapnel that had struck him four decades earlier in France, a small piece that had festered until he had removed it himself after carrying it for years. Other fragmentary traces of metal are probably among his ashes now. Through him I experienced some of the multiple legacies of his experience: remoteness, silence, wounds that do not heal. Now I think of all the questions I did not ask.It has taken nearly a century for that war to emerge from its trench-like hiding place to take its full place among the deep history of pointless sacrifices, the errors of leadership, the deaths of both young men and the dreams they might have shared. Nothing in this deep history holds even a dim candle to the Great War, the First World War, the War to End All Wars. When we observe the centenary of the Great War over the next four years, perhaps that book or essay will have been written. Soft threads connect these three books; profound generosity is for me the strongest.Haruf is a beckoning writer: come out, be in this place, open yourself to the air. A generationThere is a period of history in Britain between the end of World War I and the beginning of World War II that is rich matter for weeping. A generation had been decimated -- literally and figuratively -- and, as one voice in this novel puts it, no longer has "the freedom to think hopefully of the future." That is a freedom that has never been recovered, and it never will be. Such novels as this one transcend genre; it is nominally a book about solving a mystery, but it is far more a deep and moving landscape of Britain before, during, and after the Great War. Jacqueline Winspear gives Maisie Dobbs so fine a backstory and so rich a sensibility that the reader wishes her to wander off into another kind of fiction altogether: one that tells only the story of those who must live on after their lives have been lost, those whose dreams are inescapably ridden by horrors experienced in the trenches, and those who know in the most personal ways how deeply a nation can betray its promises. That would be a novel of crime far more devastating than even this fine one. One also wishes -- unusually -- that such an unwritten book would be longer than this first volume in a series. There can never be enough said about these betrayals and their lessons almost exactly a century later. As the hundredth anniversary of the war's onset approaches, it is useful to anticipate the questions to be asked, for the truth-telling that is still necessary. No one responsible for sacrificing a generation is still living, nor are the remnants of that generation itself alive, so we might hope for some direct inquiries, clear speaking, and the plain documentation we need in order to believe the incredible. The war is over. There is nothing to lie for, no hidden decision to cover up, no one to protect any longer. I hope we can be clear, at last and in justice, about who makes war and who dies in it. Harry Michael Connelly's novels about Harry Bosch caught my attention early in the series, and my understanding of the character continues to evolve. Harry himself is an unfinished man, matched to a profession that requires a raw and intuitive grounding in process, rather than cleverness or bold charisma. It is not by accident that Harry served as a tunnel rat in the Vietnam conflict: he is still driven in part by suspicion, and still working below the surface of things, making bare and tentative progress toward an end that remains largely invisible. It also fits that he is rapidly aging on the LAPD cold case squad, chafing under harassment by an ambitious tool at its head. Harry does not have much more time to serve in the police, therefore his cases seem to be forms of investment against the erasures of time -- and that special, haunting invisibility. As much as these novels are police procedurals, they are even better understood as personal procedurals: the detective is slow to trust anyone, hard on partners, and shows equal disdain for criminals and any other police who have "no clue as to what they were really doing here ... no idea about the mission." Here, following an ethical imperative to recover some just end for a forgotten Danish reporter murdered during the Los Angeles riots in 1991, Harry Bosch reminded me of another fictional archaeologist of California death, Lew Archer, the masterful creation of Ross MacDonald. Archer once described himself as "a garbage collector on the moral scene." Harry's moral character also reminds me of Matthew Scudder, the unlicensed New York private detective invented by Lawrence Block. (Charles Durning's death yesterday reminds me of how well he would have embodied Harry or Matt, alas.) Private detection is about initiative and intellect, a mixed amount of hubris and disdain, and much rueful cogitation. Police detection at its best includes public service, the politics of cities, attention to process and order, and a scuffed idealism still capable of surviving a compromised system and its human wreckage, often including the narrow life of the detective. The best police fiction -- and Connelly has written twenty or more examples -- has a civic, moral, faithful core, driven by nobility, conscience, and losses. There are two crimes here, one for Banks and one for Cabbot, with moments where they cross. One of the finest parts of great crime novels is when two minds expand in that crossing, one enlarging the other with questions and possibilities. There is no bitterness in these books, but hope -- at least for Banks -- and the recognition that a course of life contains many changes. Such complexities make us richer as we read. That is another advantage of these long sequences of consistently fine fiction: experiences accrue for us all. review: Union General William Tecumseh Sherman's practice of scorched earth warfare in his march across Georgia is an example of humiliation beyond defeat. AbUnion General William Tecumseh Sherman's practice of scorched earth warfare in his march across Georgia is an example of humiliation beyond defeat. Absolutely punitive, the practice sought to reverse the arrogance of secessionism and the crime of shattering the union by destroying the economy, transportation, class, culture, and cities of the Confederacy. We feel the effects still, recognizing the difficulty of renewal and recovery after thorough defeat. As it is with other firestorms, landscapes and populations bear historical scars. We recognize PTSD today, but reading  by E. L. Doctorow is a reminder that it is likely to have been a constant sickness emergent from all wars. Sherman knows this and begins his march to the sea as a way of breaking the will of the south, in part by its sheer audacity, in larger part by its uncompromising cruelties. It is clear that what has been created in the action is something that cannot be led, even by Sherman. The war is a dark forest, and the march is an excavation or an incomparable clearcutting. Its long tail is described as a living organism of many segments, comprising more than 60,000 troops, thousands of freed slaves and other hangers-on. Publishers Weekly called its episodic stories "kind of a grim Civil War Canterbury Tales." The march is a huge creeping segmented insect, irresistible and terrible. Updike called it "a floating world. It devours people and takes over their lives, digests their possessions and identities, and it carries the reader inevitably forward.Sherman's brilliant musings, vignettes of experiences among civilians, soldiers and slaves, the military moves and strategies -- are all dramatic and superb. Their destinies are suddenly entwined and common. Doctorow allows multiple voices to speak their truths without judgment, though most reasonable voices are heard from the Union side. Reading this book occasionally caused me to think about the title of a book by Chris Hedges: War is a Force that Gives us Meaning. Ironically, having seen its meaninglessness, Sherman might agree. This is a superb novel, probably Doctorow's best, full of questions that cannot be asked or even tentatively answered except in the dread of war. ...more

The narrator of this family fiction is Helen, married to Hugh and the mother of two; she has time alone while they are off to see Hugh's parents. Helen's surviving parent, Lily, is so unbearable to Helen that the husband, children and Lily have never met over the ten years of their marriage. There is Helen's grandmother as well, who lives by the sea; the novel occurs in her house above the strand. The grandmother also carries grudges eternally -- did I mention that this is an Irish family? -- and none of them is far below the surface when all the blood relations come together. The reason for the tense reunion is Declan, Helen's brother and Lily's son, who is dying of AIDS. Closeted to his family, he has two close and caring friends who are also in the house, giving nursing care, advice, and some solace. There is not enough of that solace to go around all these raw relationships. Suffused with the promise of an impending death, these lives need to change, if only to speak without lacerating each other. The novel is a dive into the transactions, resentments and errors that disable and confuse families, often until the imminence of death itself erodes the sharp edges and grudges honed over decades. review: Brooklyn inspires me to think about the history of making choices in personal lives. At midcentury, when this book is set, the limits of free will werBrooklyn inspires me to think about the history of making choices in personal lives. At midcentury, when this book is set, the limits of free will were bounded by faith and moral judgment, by biology, guilt, and suffocating beliefs. Sin appeared in hard common parlance, yet forgiveness was more obscure. Perhaps ignorance ought to be cited as well, but it was part of the accusatory landscape, a given element of the time, like cigarettes and alcohol. People made poor choices simply to resolve ambiguities, to construct a small fenced haven, or to rescue themselves from their families. By twenty, or sooner, a life path was set, and barring accidents, one followed the course as prescribed. It is one reason for the slow change of the world.Here Colm Toibin writes impeccably from within the mind of Eilis, a young Irish woman, starting out as an immigrant in postwar Brooklyn, living bullied and friendless in a cloistered rooming house, working in a ladies' department store while studying bookkeeping. She finds her way and crafts an independent life. The mysteries of her narrow experience and progress are told through her own confusions and momentary clarities, as though Toibin had copied her letters or stolen her diaries. She begins to find herself, to express an adult's self-confidence, and to inspire trust and affection in her parochial Irish world. At a Catholic church dance she and a young Italian man are drawn to each other. Then events -- a loss, a voyage, a return to the past -- teach their lessons to the innocent.The fine craft of this novel reminded me of how much fiction depends on the many small but lifelong injustices we inherit at birth. Fate is local, internal, familial far more than it is cosmic. When we think we are most free, such injustices come to us, to shut down our imagination of the difference we want to live. I do not find solace or joy in these novels, and I do not admire innocence for its own sake. The purpose of innocence is to disappear. What I found here is a kind of greatness central to the purpose of fiction: lives explained, fates determined, innocence inevitably compromised. I am piling up books by Colm Toibin; I hope to find more of this mastery in other lives he has inhabited. Brooklyn is a very fine, lingering book....more

The victimAmong the confessions of the contemporary world, this book must rate above all others. It is as clear a case of self-rescue as we can find. The victim and the willful girl of The Liar's Club and Cherry grows into chronological adulthood carrying all the burdens of those books, and more. Lit might well be an exemplification of the truth I first read about in Alice Miller's books: our upbringing gives us more than we can bear, before we can know what is being done to us. And so Mary Karr writes, marries, has a baby boy, drinks and drinks and drinks, and crashes. And fitfully recovers, crashes, recovers, and turns Catholic.If I am morose, I turn to the great classic music of the Church -- chants and masses -- perhaps for some of the same qualities Mary Karr finds in the high order, clarity of faith, and surely unequalled poetry of Catholicism. (I grew up among Catholic kids, and might easily have been one among them, had the church not opposed my long-divorced father when my parents married.) The music, the art, the language all were not part of my life until I could discover them as an adult, I regret to say. But I don't regret not being Catholic as much as I regret having grown up in the bland church of my youth. Now, Catholic cruelty and lack of generosity are clear to me. Pederasty, absolutism, papal infallibility, the dictatorial treatment of women, the anti-progressivism, anti-abortion, anti-birth control orthodoxies ... well, I could not be part of that for the shame of it. And so it's uncomfortable for me to see Mary Karr embrace the Church, though I think she needs its rites and prayers. No, that's not all, she needs more: its immense forgiveness, its image of that poor boy Jesus taking it all on, and its multiple forms of grace. I am unsure, but if it has meant her survival, I cannot complain, she is so brilliant. And yet: What thinking and writing might be forbidden to her or place her in conflict? Where does the Church cause her to stand among women and their lives? How might her astonishing gifts as a writer be compromised or unrealized beyond Lit, because the Church is so central to her life, as the bottle once was? (Two thoughts arrive now. 1. Driving home from Georgia I always notice a billboard encouraging people to trust in Jesus. I wonder what the difference might be if the sign said "Jesus trusts in you." That is, what if Jesus expressed confidence in the divine human, the ethical divine, the generous and kind centrality of our lives, in our strength to sort through ambiguities among others? I admire a faith that encourages people to live up to a reflective model (Jesus, Buddha) and to feel a fellowship among shared conflicts. 2. In the dim years of my twenties, I read a novel by A. J. Langguth called Jesus Christs, where Jesus kept showing up in different guises, a real person, a complexity, an example of imperfect humanity. And here is one more: 3. D. H. Lawrence's corporeal Jesus in The Man Who Died. I like the idea of multiple Jesuses.)Over time, we all have adored gifted and besotted writers: Hart Crane, Hemingway, Dylan Thomas, Fitzgerald, Dashiell Hammett, Faulkner, just to start. But they all died of it, as people we know in our own lives have died of it. Therefore I will take pleasure in adoring the sober Mary Karr, hoping her torments are responsive to the life of faith, but hoping with equal fervor that the fearless essayist will write more about herself as a teacher and a writer, as a sister, as a parent. We know her as a child, living a victimized and vandalized life. Here we can know her as a woman, growing through her long passage across the rope-bridge of survival. And beyond, there are always torments, no matter what our church. I wish her a long, productive life; I wish her a generous, fruitful, and forgiving genius. I also wish her continued self-rescue. It is required of us every day. review: The Cumberland County Library asked me to speak to their book group, part of the North Carolina Humanities Council "Let's Talk About It" series devoteThe Cumberland County Library asked me to speak to their book group, part of the North Carolina Humanities Council "Let's Talk About It" series devoted to Civil War fiction. I began by talking about the challenges to the reader in The Killer Angels: keeping the geographies and personalities clear, clarifying and grasping the perspectives of North and South, and the simple disadvantage of knowing how the battle comes out. But I also introduced some special challenges to reading about the Civil War itself. Old data say that 620,000 died; new data (9/21/2011) put it at 750,000. Using the first numbers, think of this: 204,000 were deaths in battle; 314,000 were deaths from disease (scurvy, typhus, dysentery, pneumonia, malnutrition): and the Union Army recorded 25,000 deaths in Confederate military prisons. (The Confederacy had poor medical service, so its losses to disease and wounds were worse. Farm boys were especially vulnerable.) Using losses and days, one table provides the deaths-per-day of American wars: For example, in World War II, 416 died each day. In Vietnam, an average of 26 died each day of the war. In the Civil War, 600 people died each day. At the Battle of Gettysburg, the topic of this novel, the 26th Regiment of North Carolina lost 714 of 800 men, 584 on the first day of fighting. The 24th Michigan Regiment lost 362 of 496 men. The 1st Minnesota Regiment lost 82 percent; the 141st Pennsylvania lost 75.7 percent. Losses were equivalent to 2% of the US population. More than 3000 horses were killed at Gettysburg.Although The Killer Angels attends to the generals and colonels in command, none of this blood is missed. The generals could walk or ride to the front line, could see the enemy in its camps, and had clear ideas of imminent reckonings. Shaara is simply brilliant in opening the hearts of his military men, allowing us to grasp their allegiances and to see them weep. To the generals, this is a moral war as well as a mortal one, and therefore it is filled with ambiguities and tensions. It is fought on American soil. It is fought against former comrades and friends. It is not about territory, kingship, faith, incursion, or transgression. It is largely about punishment, fragility, and shattered interdependence. It is leaden with variables: tactics, troops, geography, weather, arms, food, sleep, leadership, trust. History, memory, bravery, courage, resolve, loyalty, friendship, and respect are all played out, literally, on the field.Shaara's brilliance lies in his use of the monologue, diary- and letter-like personal perspectives out of the minds and perspectives of Chamberlain and Longstreet (the most compelling of the book), and Lee, whose portrait is the most detailed. He is a living saint to his men; they pause, applaud, cheer and sing for him. Bands strike up martial music in his presence. He is a source of tragic awe. General Longstreet sees him arrive early on the morning of the terrible third day of battle:Lee came out of the mists. He was tall and gray on that marvelous horse, riding majestically forward in the gray light of morning outlined against the sky, the staff all around him and behind him. review: This has been the perfect book for me, never once a disappointment over my slow months of reading it, and I am so grateful. My gratitude is enhanced bThis has been the perfect book for me, never once a disappointment over my slow months of reading it, and I am so grateful. My gratitude is enhanced by its unpredictability: Henry James has never become very readable for me, as I tried to do when I was very young. Now I see that I had been misled by a teacher who had too small a concept of the age and patience reading James requires. So I had led myself to open The Ambassadors, never quite figuring out a word of it, thinking at times it had been written through thick gauze and then translated from some other language.As a result, James has always stood as the embodiment of high sensibility, a lofty poshness of bloodless prose, hardly an American writer at all. Not Dreiser or Howells, certainly not Whitman, not Emerson. Not that kind of mastery or sensuality. How my affection for a novel about Henry James has occurred is a mystery. A mystery: I think that is the purpose reading, to find a mystery at its heart. Any reading, newspaper, diary, garden book. Why does this happen? What must happen next? How does this engender thought? What are these unprecedented thoughts?The Master was an experience of slow, interrupted reading, always in the background as I struggled to write a long chapter about the aesthetics of fiction, and how that art works within us as we read and live it. Toward the end, the essay uses the words of Mark Edmundson. "“The test of a book lies in its power to map or transform a life. The question we would ultimately ask of any work of art is this: Can you live it?” (Why Read?, p. 129) I lived this book and experienced the qualities of light in its English and Italian rooms. I noted its extraordinary feelings: the interior longing for confidence in love; the complexity and doubt of human relationships, doubling and folding over with age and memory; and the immeasurable distances between persons seated in the same room, gazing at the same sculpture, or grieving the same loss. Reading slowly, I lived Henry's thinking, lived at Henry's pace.The novel begins in 1895 and ends in 1899, just as the year turns into a new age. Henry, born in 1843, will die in 1916, outliving his siblings. William James and his wife Alice are strongly present in the final chapter; their parents, sister Alice and two brothers are present in flashbacks as well. (The mother sends a message from the grave, in fact.) This period includes a catastrophic writing failure; finding a home away from London; a retrospective view of the Civil War, inspired by a visit from Oliver Wendell Holmes; travel to Italy; surviving the loss of a beloved woman; a passionate but unconsummated friendship with a young sculptor; a family reconciliation with a view toward death. A book, therefore, about loneliness and silence; about exile and about being American; about a complicated family of genius; about responsibility and guilt; about creating a place for oneself; about sleeping alone for a long lifetime.At the end of the book, speaking about writing with the visiting Edmund Gosse (who is about to write about his own conflicted life in Father and Son) Henry is asked to tell "the moral" of planned stories he has begun to write. One story is about a man who anticipates something dreadful for all his life, not seeing until it is too late that "his own coldness" is the catastrophe. Another is about an intelligent man with a suppressed "sensuous nature." Toibin writes, "'The Moral?' Henry thought for a moment. 'The moral is the most pragmatic we can imagine, that life is a mystery and that only sentences are beautiful, and that we must be ready for change ..." The moment is celebratory and light, in fact, but it closes with these truths: Henry embodies human resonance in all its unclarity, and sentences are beautiful.Toibin is himself a master of the telling, knifepoint sentence. In a recent interview he says he once told a class, “You have to be a terrible monster to write." That is, you must be willing to cut out and thieve the intimacies of others for your fiction and coldly put them on display. And yet here, Henry James has had five years of his life, and all the ruminations in it, stolen for these pages in a way that softens his monstrosity for me, and elevates the writer's heartlessness to a form of exquisite art. It helps me to revise my thinking, and to understand the irony that the failed writer fails because he has not been heartless enough.This is a book that I will not recommend because my joy as its reader cannot be trusted or assumed to transfer, though I think it is a rare and unpredictably moving masterpiece. I am now a decade older than Henry James was in 1899 and I too am far from where I started. I understand his distances from others; his disappointments with himself; the definitive Jamesian quality of restraint and longing; the desire and captivity of words. But I can just barely imagine the density of the tapestries of James's perceptions, their great weight; the continuities traced among lives and settings; nor can I fully grasp the rooms, the images in those mindful tapestries. It iThis is the book I am taking with me to recommend when I speak to library and museum groups, and it is one that I would ask my students to study. It is a fine reading experience, and it causes the reader to want more of Solnit's other diverse writings. This is not fiction, but the book has a compelling narrative, telling sequential stories of disasters -- floods, earthquakes, terrorist attacks, monstrous explosions -- from the humane, constructive side, where experiences are rarely recorded. And, it is in a sense an "anti-fiction" because the truths Solnit tells undermine the official responses to sudden devastation, especially those that suggest the worst about human nature. Each of her chapters addresses spontaneous human recovery in contrast to governmental malfeasance and lofty ignorance. (Think of New Orleans, Hurricane Katrina, and the inept arrogance of the Bush administration.) In all of these cases, Solnit finds that it is human altruism, crafted improvisation, and collective courage that leads to community survival in times of complete loss. "In disaster we need an open society based on trust in which people are free to exercise their capacities for improvisation, altruism and solidarity. In fact, we need it all the time, only most urgently in disaster." (p.127) As the second sentence in this quotation implies, this book is an articulation of human integrity and the basis for cooperation among strangers in times of necessity. In these settings, competition is not a useful part of the struggle to survive. Reclaiming humanity is required for that. "What begins as opposition coalesces again and again into social invention, a revolution of everyday life rather than a revolt against the system." (p.285) I want librarians to read this book particularly because it emphasizes the value of integrity, of leading a life in public fearlessly. Toward the end of the book, Solnit writes, "It will require a world in which we are each other's wealth and have each other's trust. This world can be made possible only by the faith in social possibility that understanding ourselves in past disaster can give us and by the embeddedness in place and society that constitutes a sense of belonging." (p.308) This tells of a collective heroism that evolving out of a dire challenge. The book reminds me that we require the same kinds of face-to-face claiming of our strength in the face of arbitrary political disasters and perversions of the democratic process. This is a book that expands our awareness of the human capacity for courage and self-definition in times of need.
